div.l: For it was nyght and ferre might they nought
But for the loue of god they him besought
Of herborou and of ease as for her peny
The Milner ansuerd ayen if ther be eny
Such as it is yit shul ye haue your part
Myn̄ hous is streit but ye han lerned art
Ye can bi argumentis make a place
A myle brood of twenti foot of space
Lat se now if this place may suffice
Or make him rome with spech as is yoʳur gise
Now Simond seid this Iohn bi seint Cutberd
Ay is tow mery and þat is fair͗e answerd
I haue herd say that men shul take one of ij· þīngꝭes
Sike as he findis or take sike as he bringis
But speciali I pray thee host dere
Gete us sum mete and drinke ⁊and make cher͗e
And we wille paye truly at the fulle
With empti hand men may no haukis tulle
Lo here oure siluer͗e redy forto spend
The Milner to the toun̄ his dought̉ir send
For ale and brede and rostid hem a goos
And band her hors he shuld no more go loos
And in his owne chambre he made a bedde
With shetis and with chalons fair y spredde
Not from his ovne bedde ten̄ foot or twelue
His dought̉ir had a bedde al bi hirselue
Right in the same chambre by and by
It myght be no bett and the cause why
Ther nas no romer herborou in þat place
They soupid and then̄ speken̄ of solace
And drank euer strong ale at the best
And about mydnyght went they to rest
Wele hath this Milner vernysshid his hede
Ful pale he was and and for drunk ⁊and not rede
He yoxith and he spekith thurgh the nose
As he were in the quacke or in the pose
To bedde he goth and with him his wif
As any Iay was she light and iolif
So was hir ioly whistle wel y wette
The cradil at hir beddis fete was sette
To rocke and to yeue the child souke
And whan that drunk was al þat in þᵉ crouke
